What happens when an immovable force (i.e regulators) is hit by an irresistible force (i.e autonomous robotaxis)? Innovation wants to move fast while the process to regulatory change or exemption is very slow. As usual the innovators are optimistic that approval is just around the corner, yet there is no deadline for approval and an actual limit on the number of annual exemptions are capped. The irony here is that the safety regulation requires steering wheels and pedals in all vehcles. I guess they couldn't foresee an innovation that conceiving of vehicles that drive without steering wheels and pedals. The challenge for the innovators of course will be getting approval and generating revenue before they run out of investor money. Timing really is everything.

BREAKING: Reuters reports "Aptiv to cut stake in #robotaxi #tech firm Motional, stop funding." Aptiv CEO Kevin Clark said: "While our Motional JV continues to make progress on their #technology roadmap, we've decided to no longer allocate capital to it." ANALYSIS: With Argo gone, and Cruise's #driverless operations suspended (and GM cutting spending), the decision by Aptiv to cut funding likely marks the end for Motional. Of the major developers working on robotaxis, that really only leaves Waymo. That doesn't make Waymo the smartest player, but leaves the company cornered as last to grasp the risks of using public roads to test experimental robotaxi tech using non-consenting subjects as guinea pigs. The problem from here is that when Waymo inevitably harms or kills someone, it will be seen as not considering the risks to other road users. The challenge ahead is how a robotaxi developer can kill or harm anyone, and the event itself not kill the company. Waymo is furiously setting out its stall, attempting to set a narrative that the Waymo Driver is already safer than humans. But consider, humans drive more than 3 trillion miles annually in the US alone. Waymo has cumulatively 7M driverless miles. So claims about comparative safety between Waymo and humans need lots more proof yet. But the policy genie is out the bottle. NHTSA has issued a #ANPRM for impaired driving, covering #distracted, #drowsy and #drunk driving. NHTSA is planning for a long-term goal of making human drivers safer. Robotaxis may continue for a while yet (funding permitting) but the long-term policy solution to the epidemic of deaths on US roads can be seen to be making human drivers safer. That shift has happened in just the last 2 months. A webinar on NHTSA's impaired driving ANPRM was hosted by The Ojo-Yoshida Report Link: https://lnkd.in/dqit6EYX The focus for OEMs now is to install #driver #monitoring #systems #DMS, to detect for distraction and drowsiness, and to monitor that the driver is attentive and engaged in the driving task. OEMs should get the highest performing DMS they can find. It is easy to nickel & dime that decision, but it is a false economy, you'll get what you pay for. Roads will be safer with a step-change in the performance of #AEB. Forget lidar, a better price/performance trade-off comes from imaging radar. That becomes a forward facing sensor for AEB, which detects longitudinal crash risk and brakes the vehicle accordingly. The safest driver is an engaged and unimpaired human, with hands on the wheel, eyes on the road, and mind on the task of driving. NHTSA is starting to understand that. The race is now on for automakers and tier-1s to shift their focus accordingly. Aptiv's JV partner in Motional is Hyundai. Maybe Hyundai will take pole position for advocating for #safety technology to make human drivers safer. https://lnkd.in/d-HSrGM4
